source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: Typical ingot chemical composition for both heats was Zr, $1 . 3 \%$ Sn, $0 . 1 8 \%$ Fe, $0 . 0 9 \%$ Cr, $0 . 0 7 \%$ Ni and $0 . 1 3 \%$ O

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: The hollow Zircaloy2 billets were beta quenched, machined, and assembled with a zirconium liner. After heating to $6 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } .$ , the billets were extruded to $6 3 . 5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ outside diameter (OD) by $1 0 . 9 \ \mathrm { m m }$ wall (W) by length (L)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: The tubeshell sections identified as 1, 2, and 3 were then vacuum annealed for $^ { 2 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ at 663, 732, and ${ \bf 8 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ , respectively

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: After each tube reducing pass, a ${ \bf 6 2 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ for $^ { 2 \cdot \mathbf { h } }$ vacuum anneal was performed

evidence_span: High-pressure steam tests at ${ 5 2 0 ^ { \circ } } \mathbf { C }$ , $1 0 . 3 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ , and $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ were conducted

evidence_span: Measurements on the same foil specimens by the two different techniques produced equivalent results for mean precipitate diameter. The low magnification method measured a mean diameter of 0.16 μm on Specimen A2 and 0.06 μm on Specimen C1
process_step: tube reducing with different reduction schedules

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: the high magnification method measured 0.17 μm and 0.07 μm, respectively
process_step: tube reducing with different reduction schedules

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk3
STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: The growth of the intermetallic precipitates due to the higher annealing temperatures and the resulting increase in accumulated annealing parameter, ΣA_i, is clearly evident

extra_properties.precipitate_growth_trend: increases with annealing temperature and ΣA_i

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: Material from both B.b3 and H22641 1 were annealed at 800°C after extrusion, while material from C1 was annealed at 663°C, All the material was then tube reduced according to different reduction schedules with 620°C anneals after the passes to final cladding

extra_properties.process_description: occasional micro-zones of solute enrichment in typically solute-depleted matrix

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk4
evidence_span: The specimen from H226411 had very little nickel $( \mathbf { N i } )$ and chromium $( \mathbf { C r } )$ and no iron $( \mathbf { F e } )$ detected in the matrix

evidence_span: specimens from B.b3 and C1 had a slightly higher matrix concentration
composition_raw: Fe, Cr, Ni concentrations slightly higher

evidence_span: when $\Sigma A _ { i } \le 1 0 ^ { - 1 8 }$ then the nodular corrosion behavior of Zircaloy2 is acceptable in ${ 5 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } }$ steam autoclave tests

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: The 732 and $\bf { 8 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ annealed material had larger precipitates that were detrimental to the corrosion resistance when tube reduced with a low reduction schedule

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: the 732 and $8 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ annealed material with large precipitates had excellent corrosion behavior provided it was tube reduced with a high reduction schedule

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: Wadman and Andrén detected iron, chromium, and nickel at approximately $0 . 0 1 9 \%$ , $0 . 0 0 7 \%$ , and $0 . 0 1 8 \%$ by weight in the matrix of Zircaloy-2
